January 1937.SECRET. c?py Nq. 40CP. 19 (37).CABINET.PROPOSED BILL TO REMOVE DOMINICA FROM THE LEEWARD ISLANDS FEDERATION AND TO PROVIDE FOR ITS FUTURE WITHIN THE WINDWARD ISLANDS GROUP. Memorandum by the Secretary of State for the Colonies. THE Colony of the Leeward Islands at present consists of five Presidencies,namely, Antigua, St. Christopher and Nevis, Dominica, Montserrat, and theVirgin Islands. Under the Leeward Islands Act, 1871, the Colony became a federation. 2. The Governor of the Leeward Islands has recommended that Dominicashould be taken out of the Federation and included constitutionally in theWindward Islands, a group of three Colonies, Grenada, St. Lucia and St. Vincent,lying to the south of the Leeward Islands. 3. Geographically, Dominica is the most southerly island in the Leewardsgroup and lies between the two French Islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique,was formerly French and acquired by Britain in the Napoleonic wars : inphysical, linguistic, social and economic conditions, it is more closely akin to theWindward Islands than to the other Presidencies in the Leeward Islands. Astrong demand for the change has been expressed by the people of Dominica ever since its inclusion in the Leewards Federation; the proposal has also the supportof responsible people throughout the Leeward Islands and it is gathered that opinion in the Windward Islands would not be opposed to it; and no serious difficulty is anticipated with regard to finance. I have been impressed with thearguments in favour of the change, and I have come to the conclusion that, as amatter of policy, Dominica should be taken out of the Leeward IslandsFederation and included in the Windward Islands group. 4. The Law Officers have advised that Dominica cannot be taken out of theColony of the Leeward Islands except by an Act of Parliament and, further, thatit would be the better course for the Act to make provision for the future positionand status of the Island after the severance. 5. In the circumstances, I seek the approval of the Cabinet to the proposal that a Bill for the purpose should be prepared for introduction in the course ofthis session., if that can possibly be arranged. I do not anticipate that there canbe any controversy or that it will occupy time. (Initialled) W. O. G. Colonial Office, Downing Street, January 20, 1937.[14459]
